articles.headline: Businesses Chafing Under Covid-19 Lockdowns Turn to Armed Defiance
articles.snippet: Armed militia-style protesters have helped businesses across Texas defy coronavirus lockdowns and reopen. Protesters say they are enforcing the Constitution.
articles.abstract: Armed militia-style protesters have helped businesses across Texas defy coronavirus lockdowns and reopen. Protesters say they are enforcing the Constitution.
articles.lead_paragraph: SHEPHERD, Texas — When Jamie Williams decided to reopen her East Texas tattoo studio last week in defiance of the state’s coronavirus restrictions, she asked Philip Archibald for help. He showed up with his dog Zeus, his friends and his AR-15 semiautomatic rifle.
articles.byline: By Manny Fernandez and David Montgomery

articles.headline: Coronavirus Wrecked Tesla’s Momentum and Elon Musk Is Furious
articles.snippet: Mr. Musk opened his California factory this week in defiance of local orders. He has also criticized the response to the pandemic as “dumb” and “fascist.”
articles.abstract: Mr. Musk opened his California factory this week in defiance of local orders. He has also criticized the response to the pandemic as “dumb” and “fascist.”
articles.lead_paragraph: A few months ago, everything seemed to be going Elon Musk’s way, as he presided over an upstart electric car company that was worth more than General Motors, Ford Motor and Fiat Chrysler combined.

articles.headline: Born Into Carnage, 18 Afghan Babies Face an Uncertain Fate
articles.snippet: A day after gunmen stormed a maternity ward and slaughtered new mothers at random, the authorities struggled to reconnect their children with families.
articles.abstract: A day after gunmen stormed a maternity ward and slaughtered new mothers at random, the authorities struggled to reconnect their children with families.
articles.lead_paragraph: KABUL, Afghanistan — When the carnage was over, the dead bodies bagged and the guns put away, what was left behind spoke of the true extent of the tragedy: 18 newborn babies, many covered in blood and most now motherless — casualties of war before they had even left the hospital.
articles.byline: By Mujib Mashal and Jim Huylebroek

articles.headline: Small-Business Loan Deadline Poses Test for Mnuchin
articles.snippet: The Treasury Secretary has given big companies until May 18 to return their Paycheck Protection Program loans or face criminal liability. Many borrowers are rebuffing those demands.
articles.abstract: The Treasury Secretary has given big companies until May 18 to return their Paycheck Protection Program loans or face criminal liability. Many borrowers are rebuffing those demands.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — When big businesses like Shake Shack and the Los Angeles Lakers basketball franchise took millions of dollars’ worth of emergency loans intended for small businesses, Treasury Secretary Steven Mnuchin called such borrowing “outrageous,” narrowed eligibility and threatened to hold companies criminally liable if they did not give the money back.
articles.byline: By Alan Rappeport and David McCabe

articles.headline: Judge Appoints Outsider to Take On Justice Dept. in Flynn Case
articles.snippet: A retired judge will also examine whether the former national security adviser committed perjury.
articles.abstract: A retired judge will also examine whether the former national security adviser committed perjury.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The federal judge overseeing the case against President Trump’s former national security adviser Michael T. Flynn appointed a hard-charging former prosecutor and judge on Wednesday to oppose the Justice Department’s effort to drop the case and to explore a perjury charge against Mr. Flynn.

articles.headline: Why Are There Almost No Memorials to the Flu of 1918?
articles.snippet: A restaurant owner in Vermont and a  professor from New Zealand are among the few to commemorate the most lethal pandemic since the bubonic plague.
articles.abstract: A restaurant owner in Vermont and a  professor from New Zealand are among the few to commemorate the most lethal pandemic since the bubonic plague.
articles.lead_paragraph: At Hope Cemetery in Barre, Vt., a five-ton granite bench sits on a triangle of grass. It is a mere five feet high and three feet deep, which seems modest in scale relative to the calamity it commemorates.

articles.headline: Trump White House Changes Its Story on Michael Flynn
articles.snippet: Three years ago, President Trump swiftly fired his first national security adviser, Michael T. Flynn, for lying to the F.B.I. Ahead of the November election, Mr. Trump and his allies are now telling a very different tale.
articles.abstract: Three years ago, President Trump swiftly fired his first national security adviser, Michael T. Flynn, for lying to the F.B.I. Ahead of the November election, Mr. Trump and his allies are now telling a very different tale.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — After announcing that the Justice Department was dropping the criminal case against Michael T. Flynn, the former national security adviser, Attorney General William P. Barr was presented with a crucial question: Was Mr. Flynn guilty of lying to the F.B.I. about the nature of phone calls he had with the Russian ambassador to the United States?
articles.byline: By Adam Goldman and Mark Mazzetti

articles.headline: Meat Plant Closures Mean Pigs Are Gassed or Shot Instead
articles.snippet: Coronavirus outbreaks at meatpacking plants have created a backlog of animals ready for slaughter but with nowhere to go. Farmers are having to cull them.
articles.abstract: Coronavirus outbreaks at meatpacking plants have created a backlog of animals ready for slaughter but with nowhere to go. Farmers are having to cull them.
articles.lead_paragraph: One Minnesota hog farmer sealed the cracks in his barn and piped carbon dioxide through the ventilation system. Another farmer has considered gassing his animals after loading them into a truck. And a third shot his pigs in the head with a gun. It took him all day.
articles.byline: By Michael Corkery and David Yaffe-Bellany

articles.headline: ‘Rolling Shock’ as Job Losses Mount Even With Reopenings
articles.snippet: Nearly three million new unemployment claims brought the two-month total to more than 36 million, even with some still frustrated in seeking benefits.
articles.abstract: Nearly three million new unemployment claims brought the two-month total to more than 36 million, even with some still frustrated in seeking benefits.
articles.lead_paragraph: Scattershot reopenings of retail stores, nail salons and restaurants around the country have not halted the flood of layoffs, with the government reporting Thursday that nearly three million people filed unemployment claims last week, bringing the two-month tally to more than 36 million.
articles.byline: By Patricia Cohen and Tiffany Hsu

articles.headline: As Coronavirus Overruns Russia, Doctors Are Dying on the Front Lines
articles.snippet: Facing dire shortages of protective gear and amid fears that the worst is yet to come, more than 180 medical workers are reported to have fallen victim so far and thousands have been infected.
articles.abstract: Facing dire shortages of protective gear and amid fears that the worst is yet to come, more than 180 medical workers are reported to have fallen victim so far and thousands have been infected.
articles.lead_paragraph: MOSCOW — Dr. Rimma Kamalova says her hospital’s leadership ignored her warnings about an unexplained pneumonia outbreak back in March. She kept working.
